Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the polling station, phone buzzing in my pocket with messages from my project manager. The client was waiting for my time estimates before signing the contract, and the team needed my input to finalize the project plan. I tried to focus on the voting process, but my mind kept drifting back to the spreadsheet I’d left open on my laptop. Suddenly, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” I glanced at the new line—longer, slower, but following instructions was part of my civic duty as a voter. Yet, every minute spent here was a minute my team waited, the client grew impatient, and the project slipped further from certainty. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. Should I stay in the faster line and risk breaking the rules, or follow instructions and delay my work even more? My heart pounded as I shuffled my feet, caught between the demands of my profession and my duty as a citizen, unable to satisfy both at once.
